messages: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (20:04): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: what's the difference between checking for whitespace and checking for the closing quote character? whitespace can be several different characters?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:06): It's just a few more values to check for - unquoted needs to detect 9/10/11/12/32/38/62/EOF, double-quoted only needs to look for 34/38/EOF, so you'd usually need a few more comparisons in the unquoted case
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:10): I don't think it's an especially compelling reason to use HTML instead of XHTML :-)

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (20:24): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: oh, i was just surprised that mskinner's implementation experience suggested that parsing quoted attributes would be "MUST faster" than unquoted
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (20:24): http://forums.whatwg.org/viewtopic.php?t=93#395
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:44): is in Spain without luggage
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:52): looks at <img> redesign
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:53): notes that <audio> prolly needs a note about its constructor too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:56): reads molly's rant
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:56): notes that #whatwg is the new twitter
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:58): reads the comments about people being frustrated by the WHATWG now it's suddenly in the W3C

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:59): thinks the comments at http://www.molly.com/2007/08/11/dear-w3c-dear-wasp/ are quite hilarious given what has been said so far about headers= etc. on the public-html list
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (21:00): reads about edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e reading molly's rant and goes to read molly's rant.
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:00): wonders what all the fuss is about

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (21:01): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f, a disconnect between those that hold meetings, their topics/agendas, and those that work in the field day-to-day, their real-world challenges and desired solutions.
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:05): since when has WHATWG been a semi-secret society?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (21:07): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f, it is a general trolling technique
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (21:09): often used by bureaucracy trolls: http:/ f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905.pbwiki.com/TrollTaxonomy#Bureaucraytroll
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:10): semi-secret in the sense of "public". :)
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:10): I wonder when MS will send feedback on the current spec
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (21:13): nice taxomony, there

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:31): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: Maybe quoted vs unquoted matters more if you're writing an actual SGML-like HTML4 parser, since that's much more particular than HTML5 about what characters are allowed in unquoted values
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:32): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: so what would you do when you hit a character that is not allowed?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:35): Given what the W3C validator does, you sometimes start reading a new attribute name that begins with the non-allowed character

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:35): (at least for <div class=foo'bar></div> - but it seems different for <div class=foo#bar></div> since that just complains about an invalid character inside the value)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:36): assumes that sgml doesn't define what to do
2d9b4b2e6d678d91f6afbf8a0763a223 (21:36): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: SGML has no defined error handling
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:37): 2d9b4b2e6d678d91f6afbf8a0763a223: it has some
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:37): 2d9b4b2e6d678d91f6afbf8a0763a223: e.g., </foo in a cdata element closes the element but is an error if the end tag doesn't match the start tag
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:38): not sure if there are others

2d9b4b2e6d678d91f6afbf8a0763a223 (21:53): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: yes, so the error there is that is that the end tag doesn't match the start tag. But SGML doesn't define what to do in that case
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:58): 2d9b4b2e6d678d91f6afbf8a0763a223: i thought it did (namely close the element anyway)
2d9b4b2e6d678d91f6afbf8a0763a223 (22:02): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: it says that the first end-tag delimiter-in-context (i.e. ETAGO followed by a name start character) closes the element.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:03): 2d9b4b2e6d678d91f6afbf8a0763a223: yes, exactly
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:06): but yeah, i guess you could argue that it doesn't say if you should do something different in case it is an error

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (22:20): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f, thanks.  Also, I have attempted to add a rational response to the comments on molly's post: http://www.molly.com/2007/08/11/dear-w3c-dear-wasp/#comment-610009
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (22:23): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: I tried that a while ago.  never seems to do much, but I suppose one has to try
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (22:24): rationality is worth persistence

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (22:26): i'm actually optimistic that accessibility "advocates" can and will adopt more purely rational/scientific approaches to their advocacy, thus build stronger, more appealing cases for accessibility, which more will then listen to, which will hopefully result in more accessibility in technologies, tools, etc.

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (22:29): here is an example of such a rational/scientific approach in progress, thanks largely to James Craig and a few other accessibility advocates: http://microformats.org/wiki/assistive-technology-abbr-results
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (22:29): takes a look
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (22:29): I was optimistic for a while, maybe it'll return now public-html has calmed down a little
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (22:29): it's not perfect, but it's a huge step in the right direction in terms of approach etc.
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (22:32): yeah, that looks pretty good
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (22:33): we have to work on reducing the use of negative/personal rhetoric as a method of discourse - it doesn't help anybody
